repnme.cdata!:
Guinea-Bissau - Second Economic Governance
            Reform Grant Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Second Economic
            Governance Reform Grant (EGRG) Project for Guinea-Bissau
            were as follows: outcomes were satisfactory; risk to
            development outcome was substantial; Bank performance was
            satisfactory; borrower performance was moderately
            satisfactory. Some lessons learned includes: outcome
            indicators should not depend on future reports for which
            funding are not assured. EGRGs were useful in maintaining an
            agenda for reforms that had benefited from analytical and
            operational work done ahead of time and for which technical
            assistance and project support were available. Reforms that
            had been identified and understood well ahead of time helped
            secure support among development agencies. The EGRGs
            experience highlighted the importance of complementary
            technical assistance in a fragile state environment. Many of
            the reforms aimed at supporting PFM and private sector
            development were possible because, in parallel with the
            budget support, the World Bank Group International Finance
            Corporation (including IFC), provided technical assistance
            crucially given the country's weak institutional
            capacity to achieve results. The EGRGs were useful in
            compensating for the unpredictability of annual aid flows
            from more politically motivated sources of support. By
            channeling resources through the budget, instead of through
            projects, where Government decision-making and
            implementation of the government structural reform agenda
            are limited, the EGRGs instrument helped foster
            decision-making within Government. The EGRG series benefited
            from a mutually reinforcing partnership between the World
            Bank and the IMF that combined efforts to attain
            macroeconomic stability with needed structural reforms in
            areas ranging from education and health to public financial
            management and private sector development. The collaboration
            between the two institutions helped craft an implementable
            reform agenda that combined extensive technical assistance
            and funding, supported by a continuity of involvement during
            the most challenging times during this period.

repnme.cdata!:
Guinea-Bissau - Second Economic Governance
            Reform Grant Program

abstracts.cdata!:
This program document the second of a
            programmatic series of two Economic Governance Reform Grants
            (EGRGs) for the Republic of Guinea-Bissau. The operation
            supports the continuation of the selective reform agenda
            initiated by the Government in 2009 with the support of the
            EGRG I. The reform momentum under both the Public Financial
            Management (PFM) and the Private Sector Development (PSD)
            planks has been sustained. The PFM plank aims at
            consolidating the setting up of a modern legal framework for
            public financial management that is consistent with the West
            African Economic and Monetary Union (WAEMU) standards, and
            promoting compliance with this legal framework through
            systems, controls and operational reforms. The PSD plank
            aims at consolidating the setting up of a modern legal
            framework for private investment and improving the
            administrative environment for business. Both PFM and PSD
            reforms are needed jointly to restore confidence in public
            policy and institutions and support macroeconomic stability.
            The design of the reform program builds on analytical work
            in these two areas and leverages activities supported by
            other International Development Association (IDA)-funded
            instruments, including Low Income Countries Under Stress
            (LICUS) and State and Peace-building Fund (SPF) grant funded
            operations and the IDA Private Sector Rehabilitation and
            Development Project (PSRDP). The operation also complements
            support provided by the African Development Bank (AfDB),
            Portugal, the European Union (EU), the International
            Monetary Fund (IMF), and other donors in related critical areas.
